rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/0c5c5e20-246e-11e4-8c21-0800200c9a66">     <title>Soil, vegetation and geology maps of the Moor House National Nature Reserve WMS</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/0c5c5e20-246e-11e4-8c21-0800200c9a66</link>     <description>Map service of soil types, geology and vegetation in the Moor House region of the Moor House - Upper Teesdale National Nature Reserve. The site lies in the North Pennine uplands of England and has an area of 74 km2. It is England's highest and largest terrestrial National Nature Reserve (NNR), a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve and a European Special Protection Area. Habitats include exposed summits, extensive blanket peatlands, upland grasslands, pastures, hay meadows and deciduous woodland. Altitude ranges from 290 to 850 m. Moor House - Upper Teesdale is part of the Environmental Change Network (ECN) which is the UK's long-term environmental monitoring programme.</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Philip Trembath</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Environmental Change Network</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>ECN</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Moor house NNR</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>National Nature Reserve</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>UNESCO Biosphere Reserve</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Special Protection Area</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>SPA</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>geology</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>vegetation</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>North Pennines</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>England</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Upper Teesdale</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>infoMapAccessService</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2015-01-14T14:54:44Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/1b977181-a3bf-4535-b38e-32509001f7aa">     <title>Soil pH at Roudsea Wood National Nature Reserve 1961</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/1b977181-a3bf-4535-b38e-32509001f7aa</link>     <description>The dataset consists of pH values from soil samples taken in Roudsea Wood National Nature Reserve in 1961.  Soil samples were taken from between 5 and 10cm in depth from transects across the reserve and from under oak trees.  pH was measured by the Woodlands Research Section at The Nature Conservancy's Merlewood Research Station, Grange over Sands, Cumbria and the data have been stored and digitised by the Centre for Ecology & Hydrology, Lancaster.   </description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Sharon Hayton</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>woodland</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>pH</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Monitoring & Observing Systems</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2014-12-10T11:45:36Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/cc264d08-ba89-42f0-a7cf-9c9477e1e2bd">     <title>Measurements of respiration and microbial assimilation of carbon substrates and priming of soil organic matter mineralisation in tropical lowland and montane forest soils</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/cc264d08-ba89-42f0-a7cf-9c9477e1e2bd</link>     <description>This dataset includes measurements of microbial community composition by phospholipid fatty acid (PLFA) analysis, soil respiration (Carbon dioxide (CO2)), soil physico-chemical properties and 13C enrichment in CO2 samples and microbial Phospholipid Fatty Acids (PLFAs). Data were produced for an investigation of the effects of carbon (C) substrate addition on soil carbon cycling processes in ten tropical soils from the Peruvian Andes. Soils were amended with 13C labelled substrates (xylose, glycine, vanillin and hemicellulose) and incubated under controlled conditions for 7 days. </description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Jacky Chaplow</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil organic matter</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>microbial community composition</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>decomposition</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>respiration</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>priming</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>montane cloud forest</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>ecosystem function</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>bacterial</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>fungal</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Peru</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Andes</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>forest</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>tropical lowland</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>montane</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>January</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>2012</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Sustainable Land Management</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2014-11-19T15:01:16Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/7a5cfd3e-0247-4228-873d-5be563c4ee3b">     <title>Post Chernobyl surveys of radiocaesium in soil, vegetation, wildlife and fungi in Great Britain</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/7a5cfd3e-0247-4228-873d-5be563c4ee3b</link>     <description>Data comprise radiocaesium concentrations in soil, vegetation, wildlife and fungi analysed from samples collected from throughout Great Britain after the 1986 Chernobyl accident by the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology (CEH), formerly the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology (ITE). National level vegetation surveys were conducted in May 1986, October 1986 and Spring 1987. More intensive surveys of vegetation (grass and heather) and wildlife (grouse, fox, etc.) in restricted areas were carried out in Cumbria, Wales and North Yorkshire in 1989, 1990, 1991 and 1993. Surveys of fungi were carried out between 1994 and 1997. The data are suitable for interpolation to create spatially variable surfaces suitable for input into models.</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Claire Wood</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Environmental monitoring facilities</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Radioecology</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Chernobyl</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>deposition</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>radioactive</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>contamination</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>radionuclide</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>accident</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>radiocaesium</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>North Wales</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>UK</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Yorkshire</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>GB</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>STAR_NOE</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>fungi</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>vegetation</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>wildlife</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>grass</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>grasses</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>heather</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Pollution & Environmental Risk</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2014-09-25T09:02:58Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/3f22ef89-22d3-4876-a99e-7ee28f775e0e">     <title>Solute concentrations in water samples from clearfelled and standing Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) forest ecosystems, Kershope Forest</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/3f22ef89-22d3-4876-a99e-7ee28f775e0e</link>     <description>The dataset consists of solute concentrations (Potassium, Calcium, Magnesium, Iron, Sodium, Aluminium, Phosphate, Nitrate, Ammonium, Chlorine,  Sulphate), also pH and suspended solids, in waters sampled from clear felled and standing Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) forest ecosystems in Kershope Forest, Cumbria, UK.  Water samples were collected from the ecosystem of a Sitka spruce plantation at weekly intervals for six years.  The drainage system of the site had been designed to divide the plantation into a series of artificial catchments, three of which were designated experimental plots and clearfelled in the second year of sampling while three others were the control plots which remained unfelled until the end of the study.  This work formed part of a programme of field and laboratory work to determine the effects of felling plantation forest on soil processes.  Samples were collected by staff from the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology (ITE) between 1981 and 1987. </description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Claire Wood</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Environmental monitoring facilities</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>clear felling</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>clearcutting</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Conifers</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Sitka spruce</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil processes</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Great Britain</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Cumbria</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>hydrology</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>forestry</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>chemistry</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>drainage water</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>forests</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2014-08-29T15:17:43Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/9d7229b3-47c0-4255-8d57-dda863065774">     <title>Plynlimon research catchments: vegetation map</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/9d7229b3-47c0-4255-8d57-dda863065774</link>     <description>Vegetation map of Plynlimon catchments. The vegetation map was created for assisting with identifying soil survey vegetation boundaries, and is not an authoritative vegetation survey. The defined vegetation classes correspond with the classes defined in CEH Land Cover Map 2000 (LCM 2000).  LCM2000 was classified using a hierarchical nomenclature corresponding to the Joint Nature Conservation Committee (JNCC) Broad Habitats which encompasses the entire range of UK habitats. </description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Dave Norris</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Land cover</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>vegetation</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>uk</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>wales</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>plynlimon</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>severn</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>hafren</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>hore</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>tanllwyth</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>wye</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>gwy</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>cyff</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>iago</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2014-05-08T14:50:07Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/f30e4fde-634b-402a-b807-b5188d21b998">     <title>UK ecological status map</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/f30e4fde-634b-402a-b807-b5188d21b998</link>     <description>A spatial indicator of ecological status for valuation of biodiversity across the UK, based on species occurrence records was developed.  UK species occurrence data were collated from the Biological Records Centre (BRC). The mean ecological status was calculated across all taxonomic groups for the 2000 to 2013 time period, relative to the species richness maximums from the 1970-1990 time period, showing differences as colours.</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Ting Zhang</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Habitats and biotopes</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>eukaryote</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biodiversity</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>bacteria</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2014-04-30T16:19:54Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/1deb9ee0-a01c-4ce6-a5b0-a1ad32beeff7">     <title>Soil water chemistry data from Climoor fieldsite in Clocaenog Forest</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/1deb9ee0-a01c-4ce6-a5b0-a1ad32beeff7</link>     <description>This dataset includes a range of determinands present in soil water in the experimental plot at the Climoor field site in the Clocaenog Forest, in north-east Wales. Soil water was collected at two depths in the soil profile - approximately 5cm and 20cm. At the bottom of the rooting zone (approximately 5cm depth) zero tension lysimeters were used. At the deeper depth (approximately 20cm depth) ceramic cup suction samplers were used. Data were collected between October 1998 and March 2009 at two weekly intervals. Determinands include: pH, Ammonium nitrogen (NH4-N), Nitrate nitrogen (NO3-N), Sulphate (SO4-S), dissolved organic carbon, dissolved organic nitrogen, Calcium (Ca), Potassium (K), Magnesium (Mg), Sodium (Na), Phosphate phosphorus (PO4-P), Chloride (Cl), total dissolved phophorus and total dissolved nitrogen.</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Alwyn Sowerby</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Environmental monitoring facilities</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>monthly</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biogeochemistry</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>water</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2014-03-06T09:42:53Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/e9baffd1-18ad-435e-94e2-01e49c14c547">     <title>Soil properties and soil greenhouse gas emissions in biochar-amended bioenergy soils undergoing long term field incubation.</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/e9baffd1-18ad-435e-94e2-01e49c14c547</link>     <description>Data collected during field and laboratory experiments to investigate the long-term effects of biochar application to soil on greenhouse gas emissions in a bioenergy plantation (Miscanthus X. giganteus). Analysis included monitoring of greenhouse gas emissions (carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N2O)), soil physical (bulk density and soil moisture ) and soil chemical analyses (total carbon (C) and nitrogen (N), extractable ammonium and nitrate). Biochar was applied to plots in a bioenergy plantation and emissions of CO2, CH4 and N2O were measured over a 2 year period.  In addition a laboratory incubation experiment was conducted on soil taken from the Miscanthus field amended with field-incubated biochar to assess the effect on greenhouse gas emissions. Biochar is a carbon rich substances which is being advocated as a climate mitigation tool to increase carbon sequestration and reduce nitrous oxide emissions.</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Jacky Chaplow</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biochar</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>chemistry</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>N2O</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>nitrous oxide</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>greenhouse gas</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>emission</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Biogeochemistry Programme</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Shore section</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Lincolnshire</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2014-02-04T12:26:42Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/2757e972-a7fe-494d-92c3-c3205dfdef19">     <title>Soil properties and soil greenhouse gas emissions in biochar-amended bioenergy soils incubated under controlled laboratory conditions</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/2757e972-a7fe-494d-92c3-c3205dfdef19</link>     <description>Data from an investigation of the effects of biochar application to soil on greenhouse gas emissions using soil from a bioenergy crop (Miscanthus X. giganteus). Data include physical (bulk density) and chemical analyses of the soil (total carbon (C) and nitrogen (N), extractable ammonium and nitrate), and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions (carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N2O)) during incubations. Data were collected during two incubation experiments investigating the effects of temperature, soil moisture and soil aeration on biochar induced suppression of GHG emissions. Biochar is a carbon rich substances which is being advocated as a climate mitigation tool to increase carbon sequestration and reduce nitrous oxide emissions. </description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Jacky Chaplow</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biochar</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>chemistry</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>N2O</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>nitrous oxide</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>greenhouse gas</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>emission</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Biogeochemistry Programme</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Shore section</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Lincolnshire</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2014-01-16T10:14:23Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/69d89261-b7ee-4b56-bb13-1128e3c8dd93">     <title>Chemical analysis of nitrogen transformations in biochar amended soil</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/69d89261-b7ee-4b56-bb13-1128e3c8dd93</link>     <description>These data are from an investigation of the effects of biochar application to soil, on soil greenhouse gas emissions and N transformations within the soil. Biochar is a carbon rich substance which is being advocated as a climate mitigation tool to increase carbon sequestration and reduce nitrous oxide emissions. The data were collected during a 15N pool dilution incubation to investigate the nitrogen transformations within biochar-amended soil following the addition of 15N-labelled ammonium nitrate. Analyses included 15N content of nitrous oxide and 15N content of soil. The N transformations were then modelled using a model for calculating nitrogen fluxes in soil using 15N tracing (FLUAZ model).</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Jacky Chaplow</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biochar</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>chemistry</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>N2O</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>nitrous oxide</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>greenhouse gas</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Biogeochemistry Programme</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Shore section</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Lincolnshire</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Soil</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2013-10-09T12:34:35Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/78bb4a32-765e-4ecf-856b-c970179cdf25">     <title>Plynlimon research catchments: soil parent materials</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/78bb4a32-765e-4ecf-856b-c970179cdf25</link>     <description>Distribution of soil parent materials in the Severn and Wye catchments.  These were mapped during the Soil Hydrology Study conducted by JP Bell in 1968-1969: Bell, J.P. (1969). The Soil Hydrology of the Plynlimon Catchments. Institute of Hydrology Report No. 8, Institute of Hydrology, Wallingford, UK.</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Nuria Bachiller-Jareno</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>hydrology</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>hydrochemistry</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>water quality</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>uk</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>wales</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>plynlimon</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>severn</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>hafren</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>hore</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>tanllwyth</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>wye</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>gwy</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>cyff</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>iago</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>hydrological properties of soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2013-05-21T10:11:32Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/a5093d15-be48-48de-b8fd-41f573cf2b10">     <title>Farm scale evaluations of herbicide tolerant genetically modified crops - farm management data</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/a5093d15-be48-48de-b8fd-41f573cf2b10</link>     <description>This dataset consists of farm management data which includes crop drilling dates and herbicide application dates. The data relate to arable fields in which a range of ecological measurements were collected, including species counts in the following areas: weed seedbank, vegetation in the crop, field edge vegetation, invertebrates. Each field was sown with a combination of genetically modified and conventional crops, either Beet, Maize, Spring-sown Oilseed Rape or Winter-sown oilseed Rape. The data were collected as part of the Farm Scale Evaluations (FSEs), a four-year programme of research by independent researchers aimed at studying the effect that the management practices associated with Genetically Modified Herbicide Tolerant (GMHT) crops might have on farmland wildlife, when compared with weed control used with non-GM crops. Data were collected by a consortium of: the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, ITE (now the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, CEH), the Institute of Arable Crop Research (now Rothamstead Research, IACR) and the Scottish Crop Research Institute, SCRI (now the James Hutton Institute, JHI). Data were collected for four crops overall (Beet, Maize, Spring-sown Oilseed Rape and Winter-sown oilseed Rape).</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Claire Wood</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Species distribution</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>agro-ecology</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable farming</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Britain</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>vegetation</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>environmental impact</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biodiversity</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>weeds</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>seedbank</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>invertebrates</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>functional groups</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>genetically modified herbicide-tolerant crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>sugar beet</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>maize</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>oilseed rape</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>trophic interactions</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Project C01732</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Biodiversity Programme</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2012-02-27T10:10:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/ca6752ed-3a22-4790-a86d-afadaedda082">     <title>Farm scale evaluations of herbicide tolerant genetically modified crops - maize</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/ca6752ed-3a22-4790-a86d-afadaedda082</link>     <description>This dataset consists of a range of ecological measurements collected from a set of arable fields, each sown with a combination of genetically modified and conventional maize crops. Measurements include species counts in the following areas: weed seedbank, vegetation in the crop, field edge vegetation, invertebrates. The data were collected as part of the Farm Scale Evaluations (FSEs), a four-year programme of research by independent researchers aimed at studying the effect that the management practices associated with Genetically Modified Herbicide Tolerant (GMHT) crops might have on farmland wildlife, when compared with weed control used with non-GM crops. Data were collected by a consortium of: the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, ITE (now the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, CEH), the Institute of Arable Crop Research (now Rothamstead Research, IACR) and the Scottish Crop Research Institute, SCRI (now the James Hutton Institute, JHI). winter oilseed rape</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/37a503da-d75c-4d72-8e8b-b11c2fdc7d92</link>     <description>This dataset consists of a range of ecological measurements collected from a set of arable fields, each sown with a combination of genetically modified and conventional winter-sown oilseed rape crops. Measurements include species counts in the following areas: weed seedbank, vegetation in the crop, field edge vegetation, invertebrates. The data were collected as part of the Farm Scale Evaluations (FSEs), a four-year programme of research by independent researchers aimed at studying the effect that the management practices associated with Genetically Modified Herbicide Tolerant (GMHT) crops might have on farmland wildlife, when compared with weed control used with non-GM crops. Data were collected by a consortium of: the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, ITE (now the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, CEH), the Institute of Arable Crop Research (now Rothamstead Research, IACR) and the Scottish Crop Research Institute, SCRI (now the James Hutton Institute, JHI).
